Chamba

Chamba lies in northwest Himachal, where the Ravi River flows between the Dhauladhar and Pir Panjal ranges. The town sits on a flat ridge above the river, old palaces on one side and temples on the other. People here still live close to the land, farming wheat, rajma, and maize on terraces, keeping sheep and cows, and walking long distances through steep valleys.

Summers are pleasant, monsoon brings heavy rain, and by winter many roads close under snow. This isolation has kept Chamba’s ways intact. Wool shawls, chukh (red chilli paste), and folk songs are still part of daily life.

Our Hidden Favourites

  • Saho Hanuman Temple - About 19 km from town, Saho village has a peaceful Shiva temple and a tall Hanuman idol in the courtyard. The walk through its narrow lanes gives an authentic feel of local life.
  • Chhatrari Devi Temple - Built in the 8th century by Raja Meru Varman, this small hill temple is famous for its ancient Shakti Devi idol made of metal. During the Manimahesh Yatra, water from the lake is used to bathe the idol. The temple stands quietly among cedar trees and freshwater springs.
  • Bhalei Mata Temple - About 35 km from Chamba, this temple is dedicated to Bhadrakali. Locals visit during Navratri, walking through forests to offer prayers. The view of Dalhousie hills from here is one of the best in the district.
  • Bhandal Valley - Near Salooni, this untouched valley is full of apple orchards and pine woods. In summer, cattle graze on its meadows; in winter, it lies silent under snow. It’s also a route toward Jammu’s Kishtwar region.

Towns & Villages

  • Chamba Town: The district’s heart. The wide Chaugan ground hosts fairs and gatherings. Landmarks include the Bhuri Singh Museum and the ancient Lakshmi Narayan temples. The bazaar sells wool, copperware, and spices.
  • Bharmour: Once the capital of old Chamba rulers. Known for its Chaurasi temples and as the starting point for the Manimahesh Yatra. Pilgrims bathe at the nearby Bharmani Mata temple before the climb. It is busy in summer and snowbound in winter.
  • Pangi Valley: A world of its own beyond the Sach Pass. Open only for a few months in summer, it features small, scattered villages. The Pangwal people live tough lives, focused on small-scale farming and herding through short summers.
  • Salooni: A small town near the Jammu border, surrounded by tall pines. It is known for apple orchards and a nearby wildlife sanctuary. It serves as a base for trekkers heading toward Bhandal or the Padri Pass.

Culture & Festivals

  • Minjar Mela: Held in July or August, this festival celebrates harvest and brotherhood. People wear silk tassels called *minjar* and offer them to the Ravi River after a week of songs, wrestling, and fairs.
  • Suhi Mata Fair: Celebrated in spring, this fair remembers the sacrifice of Rani Suhi, who gave her life to bring water to the town. Women sing for her at the Suhi Mata temple.
  • Manimahesh Yatra: In August, thousands of pilgrims walk from Bharmour to Manimahesh Lake, a long journey filled with devotion and simplicity.
  • Temples and Belief: Temples are everywhere: the stone Lakshmi Narayan shrines in town, Chamunda Devi on the hilltop, and small wooden temples in every village. Religion here is lived quietly through work, food, and fairs.
  • Local Craft Influence: The famous Chamba Rumal embroidery and handmade *chappals* (slippers) often carry these temple designs, showing the connection between craft and faith.

Education & Youth

  • Schooling: Most villages have schools (primary and secondary).
  • Higher Education: Chamba town has an old government college located in the former royal palace. There are also degree colleges in Salooni and Chowari.
  • Vocational Training: A polytechnic center is available at Banikhet, providing technical skills training.
  • Migration & Return: Many youngsters leave for higher studies in Pathankot or Chandigarh. They often return to start small businesses or join local government jobs.
  • Local Sports: Wrestling, cricket, and kabaddi are local favorites. During fairs, matches are frequently organized and draw large crowds.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Daily Meals: Meals in Chamba are plain and warm. The base consists of **Wheat rotis**, dal, rice, and greens like spinach or turnip leaves. Every kitchen keeps a jar of **chukh** (fiery chili paste mixed with lime and salt).
  • Festive Dishes: During weddings or festivals, people cook **rajma madra**, **chha gosht** (mutton in yogurt gravy), and **meetha chawal** (sweet rice with nuts and saffron).
  • Winter Warmers: In winter, **butter tea** and **chhaang** (local barley brew) are consumed to keep the cold away.
  • Eateries: At dhabas, a simple thali of dal, rice, and *saag* tastes like home food. The cooking is honest, traditional Himachali style.
  • Town Bazaar: The town bazaar is simple, selling basic goods like rajma, brass utensils, **shawls**, and slippers. Women sell hand-embroidered **Chamba Rumals**.
  • Weekly Haats: Weekly local markets bring fresh seasonal produce such as peas, cauliflower, and apples, along with ghee (clarified butter).

Travel & Geography

  • Nearest Gateway: The nearest big town is Pathankot, around 110 km away.
  • Transport & Routes: Buses and taxis climb through Dalhousie and Khajjiar before reaching Chamba. Roads are narrow but scenic.
  • Seasonal Closures: Passes like Sach remain closed until May, and landslides are common during the monsoon season.
  • Best Time to Visit: The best time to visit is between April and June (pre-monsoon summer) or after the heavy rains in October.
  • Altitude Range: Chamba town sits at around 1,000–2,000 meters, but regions like Bharmour and Pangi rise much higher.
  • Landscape Diversity: The landscape changes rapidly from river valleys (with wheat fields and pine forests) to bare alpine slopes, all within a single drive.

Respect & Etiquette

  • Local Demeanor: People here are humble and soft-spoken. A simple smile and a “Jai Ram ji ki” or “Namaste” will always be returned.
  • Sacred Spaces:
    • When visiting temples, remove your shoes and dress modestly.
    • During festivals, cover your head in temples and avoid pushing in crowds.
    • Do not touch sacred objects unless invited, and do not play loud music near these areas.
  • Hospitality: If a villager offers you tea or food, accept it—it’s a gesture of warmth and respect.
  • Photography & Privacy: Do not photograph people without asking for permission first.
  • Environmental Conduct: Do not litter; carry your waste back with you.
  • General Attitude: Chamba doesn’t ask for much, just respect for its ways and silence for its hills.
